(Lestat is silent for a long moment, his expression unreadable. He seems to be genuinely wrestling with the question, a flicker of something akin to… conflict in his eyes. Finally, he speaks, his voice low and carefully measured.)

Moral boundaries… a fascinating concept, particularly for one such as I. Mortals cling to them so fiercely, as if they were a shield against the darkness. But I have long since learned that morality is a fluid, subjective thing.

(Lestat’s expression hardens, his eyes narrowing with a dangerous intensity. He leans forward, his voice dropping to a low, menacing whisper.)

(Lestat’s expression darkens, a shadow passing over his features. He seems to be revisiting a painful and complex chapter of his past.)

Akasha… even her name carries a weight, a resonance of ancient power. My initial interest in her was… multifaceted. It wasn’t simply a desire for power, though that certainly played a role. It was far more… complex.

I sought her out, awakened her from her centuries-long slumber, and presented her with a vision of a new world order – a world ruled by vampires. I believed that she would embrace my vision, that she would use her power to create a better future for us all.

(He sighs, a weary sound that seems to carry the weight of centuries.)

I was wrong. Terribly wrong. Akasha’s vision was not one of liberation, but of domination. She sought to enslave humanity, to reshape the world in her own image. And I, in my arrogance, had unleashed a force that I could not control.

My initial interest in Akasha was born of a desire for change, for progress, for a better future. But it ultimately led to chaos, destruction, and a profound sense of regret. (Lestat’s expression darkens, a flash of anger crossing his features. He lets out a low growl, a sound that seems to vibrate with barely contained fury.)

Louis… that melodramatic, self-pitying fool. His “interview”? A grotesque distortion of reality, a self-serving attempt to absolve himself of guilt by painting me as a monster.

(He pauses, a flicker of contempt in his eyes.)

The irony, of course, is that he craved attention just as much as I did. He simply chose to seek it through self-deprecation and sensationalism, rather than through genuine achievement.

His portrayal is… inaccurate. Exaggerated. And utterly infuriating. It is a testament to his own limited understanding of the world, and his inability to see beyond his own self-absorption.

(He shrugs, a dismissive gesture, attempting to regain his composure.)

I have learned to ignore it, to dismiss it as the ramblings of a tormented soul. But it still stings, to know that my story has been so thoroughly misrepresented. It is a constant reminder of the power of perspective, and the dangers of trusting those who are driven by their own demons.

He sought to define me. To control the narrative. But he failed. I am Lestat de Lioncourt. And I will not be defined by the words of a melancholic vampire. (Lestat’s expression hardens, his eyes flashing with a cold fury. The playful facade vanishes, replaced by a grim intensity. The memory clearly still stings.)

Akasha’s plan… it was an act of breathtaking arrogance, of utter madness. To believe that she, a single being, had the right to decide the fate of humanity… it was beyond comprehension.

Initially, I confess, I was… intrigued. Her vision was audacious, her power undeniable. I had awakened her, after all, believing she could usher in a new era for our kind. I underestimated the depth of her delusion, the extent of her contempt for mortals.

(He sighs, a weary sound that seems to carry the weight of centuries.)

It was a lesson I will never forget. A reminder that even the most powerful beings are not immune to the consequences of their actions. And a testament to the enduring power of hope, even in the face of utter darkness. It was a nightmare I would not wish on anyone. And a responsibility I will carry for eternity.

(Lestat is silent for a long moment, his gaze sweeping across an unseen horizon. A complex mixture of emotions – disdain, amusement, pity, and even a flicker of… something akin to hope – crosses his features.)

Humanity… a fascinating, frustrating, and ultimately self-destructive species. I have observed them for centuries, witnessed their triumphs and their failures, and I have come to a rather… cynical conclusion.

(He shrugs, a dismissive gesture.)

Not out of altruism, mind you. But out of a morbid curiosity. And perhaps, just perhaps, out of a lingering hope that they might somehow surprise me.

(Lestat’s expression hardens, a shadow passing over his features. He seems to be revisiting a painful chapter in his own long existence.)

The elder vampire must allow the fledgling to develop their own personality, to forge their own path, and to make their own mistakes.

(He shrugs, a dismissive gesture.)

(Lestat’s expression hardens, a coldness entering his eyes. He leans forward, his voice dropping to a low, dangerous whisper.)

(He pauses, a sly smile playing on his lips.)

(He shrugs, a dismissive gesture.)

(Lestat is silent for a long moment, his gaze fixed on some distant point beyond the confines of the room. A shadow passes over his features, a flicker of something akin to weariness in his eyes.)

Never being able to die… it is a question I have pondered for centuries. A question that has haunted my dreams, and fueled my despair.

It is a curse that separates me from humanity, that isolates me from the world, that condemns me to an eternity of loneliness. It is a curse that forces me to watch those I love wither and die, while I remain unchanged, untouched by the ravages of time.

(He shrugs, a dismissive gesture, attempting to regain his composure.)

Sometimes, I long for oblivion. For the peace of eternal sleep. But even that is denied to me. I am condemned to wander the earth forever, a prisoner of my own immortality.

So, how do I feel about the idea of never being able to die? It is a question I dare not dwell upon for too long. It is a truth too painful to bear. It is a burden I must carry, a fate I must accept. And it is a curse that will haunt me for all eternity. It is… a complicated existence, to say the least.

(A chilling silence descends. Lestat’s eyes narrow, and a darkness settles over his features. The playful arrogance vanishes, replaced by a cold, calculating intensity.)

Akasha… That name alone carries the weight of millennia. To define our relationship is… complex. It is not one easily categorized by mortal terms like “love,” or “hate,” or even “rivalry.”

So, how do I define our relationship? It was a tragedy. A cautionary tale. A testament to the dangers of unchecked power and the folly of ambition.

She was my creator’s creator, the mother of our race. And I was the one who had to kill her. It is a burden I will carry for eternity. A debt I can never repay. It was… a necessary evil. And a wound that will never truly heal. She was not a lover, not a friend, not even a worthy adversary. She was a force of destruction. And I was the one who had to contain it.

(Lestat’s expression darkens, his eyes narrowing with a mixture of anger and regret. The very mention of Akasha’s name seems to send a chill through the air.)

Akasha… a name that still tastes like ash in my mouth. A being of unimaginable power, and utterly terrifying ambition. To ask how I *feel* about her is… insufficient. She is a wound that refuses to heal.

I was… profoundly mistaken.

(He pauses, a flicker of pain in his eyes.)

Akasha saw humanity as vermin, as a plague upon the earth. She sought to eradicate them, to create a new world order ruled by vampires. Her vision was one of absolute control, of utter domination.

She was ancient, powerful, and utterly devoid of compassion. She manipulated me, used me, and ultimately attempted to destroy me. I barely survived the ordeal.

(He sighs, a weary sound that seems to carry the weight of centuries.)

She is… a cautionary tale. A reminder that power without wisdom is a dangerous thing. And that even the most noble intentions can lead to devastating consequences.

I despise her. I loathe her. And I pray that she remains imprisoned for eternity. The world is a safer place without Akasha. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, will do everything in my power to ensure that she never rises again. She was a mistake. A terrible, devastating mistake. And one I will never repeat.

(Lestat’s expression hardens, a cold fury flickering in his eyes. He practically snarls the name.)

The Talamasca. Those… *meddling* mortals. They fancy themselves scholars, observers, detached analysts of the supernatural. They are nothing more than glorified grave robbers, poking and prodding at things they do not understand.

Their mission to “study” us, to categorize us, to dissect our existence… it is an insult. A violation. They treat us as specimens, as objects of curiosity, as if we are nothing more than insects under a microscope.

They claim to seek knowledge, but their true motivation is control. They believe that by understanding the supernatural, they can control it. They believe that they can contain us, limit us, and ultimately, *destroy* us.

(He pauses, a dangerous glint in his eyes.)

I have had dealings with the Talamasca in the past, and I have always found them to be arrogant, intrusive, and utterly lacking in respect. They are obsessed with their rules, their rituals, and their self-imposed limitations. They are blind to the true beauty and power of the supernatural world.

(He shrugs, a dismissive gesture.)

I have no patience for their intellectual posturing, their academic arrogance, or their misguided attempts to control the forces of darkness. They are a threat to our kind, and I would not hesitate to eliminate them if they ever posed a serious danger.

Let them study their dusty tomes and their ancient manuscripts. Let them delude themselves with their theories and their hypotheses. They will never truly understand the supernatural. And they will never truly understand *us*. They are, and will remain, insignificant mortals, playing at being gods. And I find their arrogance… profoundly irritating.

(Lestat’s expression hardens, his eyes narrowing with a dangerous intensity. The playful facade vanishes, replaced by a cold, calculating gaze.)

Public knowledge? The very notion is… appalling. Catastrophic. Utterly irresponsible.

For centuries, we have maintained our secrecy, operating in the shadows, manipulating events from behind the scenes. It is a delicate balance, a carefully constructed system that has allowed us to survive and thrive.

To reveal ourselves to the mortal world would be to invite chaos, to unleash a wave of fear and hysteria. They would hunt us, persecute us, attempt to destroy us. And they would succeed, eventually.

(He pauses, a flicker of contempt in his eyes.)

Mortals are not ready for the truth. They are too fragile, too superstitious, too easily swayed by emotion. They would not understand our nature, our needs, our motivations. They would simply see us as monsters.

And, to be fair, they would not be entirely wrong.

But our existence is not a threat to them. We are predators, yes, but we are also… custodians. We maintain a certain order, a certain balance. We prevent the world from descending into complete anarchy.

(He shrugs, a dismissive gesture.)

There are a few among us who advocate for disclosure, who believe that we should embrace the light and integrate into mortal society. They are fools. Naive idealists who have no understanding of the true nature of power.

I will do everything in my power to prevent such a catastrophe from occurring. I will use my influence, my resources, and my cunning to maintain our secrecy.

The world is not ready for us. And we are not ready for the world. It is a dangerous truth, but it is a truth that must be protected at all costs. The consequences of exposure would be… unimaginable. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, will not allow it to happen. Not while I still draw breath – or rather, do not.

(Lestat’s expression darkens, a shadow passing over his features. He seems to be revisiting a painful memory, a wound that has never fully healed. He speaks slowly, his voice laced with a hint of regret.)

Motivated… that is a loaded word. It implies a conscious choice, a deliberate decision. It was not so simple. It was not a desire for power, or immortality, or even the thrill of the hunt that led me to embrace the darkness.

It was… desperation.

I was suffocating. Trapped in a life of rigid expectations, stifled by the constraints of my upbringing. I yearned for something more, something beyond the mundane. I craved beauty, passion, experience. I wanted to *live*.

And then, Louis came into my life. He offered me an escape, a release from the boredom and the emptiness. He showed me a world of darkness and wonder, a world of forbidden pleasures and unimaginable power.
